BiblioData.Title: METHOD FOR PREPARING CORE- SHELL TYPE NANOPARTICLES
BiblioData.Abstract: Disclosed herein are core-shell type nanoparticles comprising nanoparticle cores made of a metal or semiconductor, and shells made of crystalline metal oxide formed on the surfaces of the nanoparticle cores, as well as a preparation method thereof. According to the disclosed invention, the core-shell nanoparticles, consisting of metallic or semiconductor cores and crystalline metal oxide shells, can be prepared by epitaxially growing metal oxide on the surfaces of the metallic or semiconductor nanoparticle cores. By virtue of the crystalline metal oxide shells, the core nanoparticle made of metal or semiconductor can ensure excellent chemical and mechanical stability, and the core-shell nanoparticles can show new properties resulting from the interaction between the metal cores and the metal oxide crystal shells.

Claims.P: 1. Core-shell type nanoparticles comprising:

a) nanoparticle cores made of a material selected from the group consisting of the metals of Groups 3-15 of the periodic table, metalloids, lanthanide metals, actinide metals, alloys of two or more of said elements, and semiconductor compounds; and
b) shells made of crystalline metal oxide or metalloid oxide formed on the surfaces of the nanoparticle cores.

2. The core-shell type nanoparticles according to claim 1, wherein the nanoparticle cores are made of a material selected from the group consisting of Au, Ag, Pt, Pd, Co, Ni, Fe, alloys of two or more of said elements, CdSe, ZnS, and CdS.
3. The core-shell type nanoparticles according to claim 1, wherein the shells are made of a material selected from the group consisting of SiO2, ZrO2, TiO2, ZnO, and SnO2.
4. The core-shell type nanoparticles according to claim 1, wherein the shells are formed by epitaxial crystal growth on the surfaces of the cores.
5. The core-shell type nanoparticles according to claim 1, wherein the nanoparticle cores have a mean diameter of 3-200 nm.
6. The core-shell type nanoparticles according to claim 1, wherein the shells have a thickness of 3-50 nm.
7. A method for preparing core-shell type nanoparticles as defined in claim 1, the method comprising the steps of:

a) dispersing, in a mixed solvent of water and a first organic solvent, nanoparticle cores made of a material selected from the group consisting of the metals of Groups 3-15 of the periodic table, metalloids, lanthanide metals, actinide metals, alloys of two or more of said elements, and semiconductor compounds; and

b) dropping a metal oxide or metalloid oxide precursor dissolved in a second organic solvent into the solution prepared in step a), thereby forming core-shell type nanoparticles comprising shells made of crystalline metal oxide or metalloid oxide formed on the surfaces of the nanoparticle cores.
8. A method for preparing core-shell type nanoparticles as defined in claim 1, the method comprising the steps of:

a) dispersing nanoparticle cores made of a material selected from the group consisting of the metals of Groups 3-15 of the periodic table, metalloids, lanthanide metals, actinide metals, alloys of two or more of said elements, and semiconductor compounds, and dissolving a metal oxide or metalloid oxide precursor in a first organic solvent; and

b) dropping a mixed solvent of water and a second organic solvent into the solution prepared in step a), thereby forming core-shell type nanoparticles comprising shells made of crystalline metal oxide or metalloid oxide formed on the surfaces of the nanoparticle cores.
9. The method according to claim 7, wherein the crystalline metal oxide or metalloid oxide shells are formed at a temperature of 5-40[deg.] C.
10. The method according to claim 8, wherein the crystalline metal oxide or metalloid oxide shells are formed at a temperature of 5-40[deg.] C.

11. The method according to claim 7, wherein the volume ratio of water and the first organic solvent is controlled to 1:3 to 1:10000, such that reaction rate is adjusted to an extent that the hydrolysis of the metal oxide or metalloid oxide precursor can be completed within 1-60 minutes.

12. The method according to claim 8, wherein the volume ratio between water and the second organic solvent is controlled to 1:3 to 1:10000, such that the hydrolysis of the metal oxide or metalloid oxide precursor can be completed within 1-60 minutes.
13. The method according to claim 7, wherein the first or the second organic solvent is selected from the group consisting of alcohols, amides, and nitrites.
14. The method according to claim 8, wherein the first or the second organic solvent is selected from the group consisting of alcohols, amides, and nitriles.
15. The method according to claim 7, wherein the metal oxide or metalloid oxide precursor is selected from the group consisting of alkoxides, carboxylates, and halides of metal or metalloid.
16. The method according to claim 8, wherein the metal oxide or metalloid oxide precursor is selected from the group consisting of alkoxides, carboxylates, and halides of metal or metalloid.
17. The method according to claim 7, wherein carboxylic acid, [beta]-diketone, or a mixture thereof is added during step a) or b) as an additive for controlling reaction rate.
18. The method according to claim 8, wherein carboxylic acid, [beta]-diketone, or a mixture thereof is added during step a) or b) as an additive for controlling reaction rate.

19. The method according to claim 7, wherein the rate of the dropping in step b) is low enough that the metal oxide or metalloid oxide can uniformly form the shells on the surfaces of the nanoparticle cores while it can epitaxially grow into crystals.
20. The method according to claim 7, wherein the rate of the dropping in step b) is 5 [mu]l/sec to 1 Ml/sec per 100 mg of the nanoparticle cores.
21. The method according to claim 8, wherein the rate of the dropping in step b) is 5 [mu]l/sec to 1 Ml/sec per 100 mg of the nanoparticle cores.
